MUSICAL CLUB WILL
GIVE TWO CONCERTS
to

Easton
To Take Trip
and Salisbury
TO LEAVE WEDNESDAY
Club Plans Other Trips
Later in Season
The Musical Club will give two
concerts during the Christmas holidays, one at Easton and another at
Salisbury.
On Wednesday, December 26, the
members'of the club (approximately
seventy, strong) will set out
from the barn by bus for Easton,
Md., which is.located on the Eastern
Shore. That night they will give a
Concert -at the Easton High School
under the auspices of the Easton
High—School Senior Class. This
concert will be followed by a dance
at the Easton Armory.'

SENIOR CLASS DUES
PAYABLE JAN. 7-11
Senior class dues will be collected during the week of January 7, immediately following
the Christmas recess. Treasurer Medenbach,will be at the
Hullabaloo office on the second floor of the "Barn" on
these days between 12:30 and
1:00 P. M, to receive payments from seniors. Dues are
twenty-nine dollars and checks
should be made payable to M.
H. Medenbach.

SWIMMING TEAM TO
CONTINUE PRACTICE
The swimming team will
hold regular practice during
the Christmas holidays. The
team will work out every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday
at 5.00 P.-M., at the Knight
of Columbus pool at Madison
and Cathedral Streets. Berause of the comparatively
slow start in reorganizing the
sport, it is absolutely necessary

Your correspondent has been
found guilty, his rollicking friends
and drunken companions tell him,
of violating a tradition, to wit, the
tradition against using names in this
column. Holding high their hands
in holy horror they demand to know
what the NEws-LETTER in general
and this part of it in particular arc
coming to. Names, they say, were
never used before; let them there'
fore be never used again.
In reply, the writer can only
shrug lightly two shoulders which
bear so many • of the world's cares
and ask with scorn and disgust,
what the hell. If tTaltions are
against the use of names, so much
the worse for the traditions.
There is in our, system of jurisprudence a very good—iedson for
following precedents, for letting, as
we say in Latin, "the' decision
stand." Security in personal and
property rights demands such a policy; there is no such demand on the
editor of this column.

AN APPRECIATION
5, Charles Dickens,
Paris, XVI.
6 December, 1928.
To the Editor if the NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir:
One of my former students has
been good enough to send me the
too generous review of Never, Go
Back which appeared in the NewsLETTER of November 13th. I am
more than touched by the friendly
tone of this notice and by the enthusiasm with which you write of
my first novel. There is, however,
one point which hurts a bit, if you
don't mind my saying so, and that
is that your reviewer, who apparently knows me, should have made the
mistake of all the others and identified me with Francis Harper. The
book is not an autobiography and
none of the characters are portraits
of the author. Moreover, Oralia
is no place on earth that I know of
but a combination of many places.
I make these remarks' because now
as in the past there has been too
much talk about the originals in my
stories and too little about the stories themselves. There is a certain
excuse for this, even in the present
ease, but there are excuses for almost everything. I should be very
grateful to you if you would make
it clear to your readers that my novel is not a roman a clef.
With many thanks I am
Faithfully yours,

GEORGE BOAS.

A use, we are delighted to announce. has been found at last for
those mysterious green apples which
sometimes grace the dining hall. Of
small value its the metabolic process,
they may nevertheless he used effectively as hand grenades, missiles,
and billets doux. and this week they
were.
Here it was nearly Christmas,
and,the boys from the Far North
(New York and Boston)'Were missing the old snow bottles; the boys
from the Far West (Los Angeles)
were still finding fault with the climate but are willing to see some
snow; aud the others were ready for
action.
At first- the apples were -just
tossed about in a mild game of
catch. Then the pace grew gradually swifter, the aims rapidly less
accurate, the casualties quickly more
numerous, reprisals initnediately the
order of the day.
And through all the fierce heat
of that bloody shambles rose and
fell .the haunting strains of the
Alumni Hall anthem, while somewhere a saxophone slowly wailed
the opening bars of Auld Lang
Sync.
Thy baa-a-attered halls,
Thy aaaappled walls,
We'll chair-ish thee for aye.
So send an aaappu11111
Through the air
And smaaaack him innnnn
the eye.
Touching.
A noble sport, you say? Wait,
brother, wait; you ain't seen nothin.
yet.
When a ,blanket of virgin snow
shall have transformed the Hall
quadrangle into a broad expanse of
purity, when an instinct as old as
the race shall have brought forth
to battle the contingents of the several entries, when a spark shall have
inflamed the gathering and awakened primordial impulses, then shall
you see action.
Until then, hold your breath.

MUSICAL CLUB WILL
GIVE TWO CONCERTS
to

Easton
To Take Trip
and Salisbury
TO LEAVE WEDNESDAY
Club Plans Other Trips
Later in Season
The Musical Club will give two
concerts during the Christmas holidays, one at Easton and another at
Salisbury.
On Wednesday, December 26, the
members'of the club (approximately
seventy, strong) will set out
from the barn by bus for Easton,
Md., which is.located on the Eastern
Shore. That night they will give a
Concert -at the Easton High School
under the auspices of the Easton
High—School Senior Class. This
concert will be followed by a dance
at the Easton Armory.'

SENIOR CLASS DUES
PAYABLE JAN. 7-11
Senior class dues will be collected during the week of January 7, immediately following
the Christmas recess. Treasurer Medenbach,will be at the
Hullabaloo office on the second floor of the "Barn" on
these days between 12:30 and
1:00 P. M, to receive payments from seniors. Dues are
twenty-nine dollars and checks
should be made payable to M.
H. Medenbach.

Your correspondent has been
found guilty, his rollicking friends
and drunken companions tell him,
of violating a tradition, to wit, the
tradition against using names in this
column. Holding high their hands
in holy horror they demand to know
what the NEws-LETTER in general
and this part of it in particular arc
coming to. Names, they say, were
never used before; let them there'
fore be never used again.
In reply, the writer can only
shrug lightly two shoulders which
bear so many • of the world's cares
and ask with scorn and disgust,
what the hell. If tTaltions are
against the use of names, so much
the worse for the traditions.
There is in our, system of jurisprudence a very good—iedson for
following precedents, for letting, as
we say in Latin, "the' decision
stand." Security in personal and
property rights demands such a policy; there is no such demand on the
editor of this column.

3

AN APPRECIATION
5, Charles Dickens,
Paris, XVI.
6 December, 1928.
To the Editor if the NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir:
One of my former students has
been good enough to send me the
too generous review of Never, Go
Back which appeared in the NewsLETTER of November 13th. I am
more than touched by the friendly
tone of this notice and by the enthusiasm with which you write of
my first novel. There is, however,
one point which hurts a bit, if you
don't mind my saying so, and that
is that your reviewer, who apparently knows me, should have made the
mistake of all the others and identified me with Francis Harper. The
book is not an autobiography and
none of the characters are portraits
of the author. Moreover, Oralia
is no place on earth that I know of
but a combination of many places.
I make these remarks' because now
as in the past there has been too
much talk about the originals in my
stories and too little about the stories themselves. There is a certain
excuse for this, even in the present
ease, but there are excuses for almost everything. I should be very
grateful to you if you would make
it clear to your readers that my novel is not a roman a clef.
With many thanks I am
Faithfully yours,

GEORGE BOAS.
